David Saff wrote on 12/11/09 06:55 AM:
>  
> 
> Bill,
> 
> JUnit by itself probably can't help--it assumes that once a JVM is
> started with a list of tests, it's job is to plow through those tests
> with that JVM. ant has the ability to specify forking strategies, but
> I'm not sure how that would be exposed to maven, being green in the
> ways of maven myself.
> 
> All that said, your class under test is poorly designed for
> testability, as you know, and in the Sean Connery school of test
> warfare, it may be time to break out a bigger gun. Have you
> considered using evil reflection tricks to change the private state of
> the class under test after load time?

Well, the class was designed before JUnit existed, so testability wasn't
as well understood back then.

And most of our testing to date has been done using the JavaTest harness,
which runs *every* test in its own JVM.  Yes, overkill in the other
direction.

Yes, I've considered reflection, but I think it's better to control the
environment in which the test executes.

I guess the take-away from this discussion is that JUnit doesn't have
anything to help me and I'm pretty much on my own.  :-(

Anyway, that's to everyone for the suggestions.
